Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant’s failure to maintain a habitable apartment and ensure adequate heat during the winter months has interfered with her right to live in the premises peacefully, free from substantial interference with her use and enjoyment of the property, as required under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 20, as Housing Court has subject matter jurisdiction over landlord-tenant disputes, including claims arising under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

105 C.M.R. 410.201.proposition: The Premises include a heating system, which Defendant is obligated to repair and maintain in habitable and functional condition in accordance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.201 and G.L. c. 111, § 127A.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: The Premises include a heating system, which Defendant is obligated to repair and maintain in habitable and functional condition in accordance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.201 and G.L. c. 111, § 127A.

*Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Rental.raw_text: *Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Rental Housing Corp.*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 1108 (2007)
*Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Rental.proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair the heating system or take reasonable measures to abate the problem forced Plaintiff to incur additional living expenses, including the costs of space heaters and increased electricity bills, in violation of the implied warranty of habitability and the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair the heating system or take reasonable measures to abate the problem forced Plaintiff to incur additional living expenses, including the costs of space heaters and increased electricity bills, in violation of the implied warranty of habitability and the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement where the tenant suffered loss of heat and hot water, but it does not discuss or award consequential damages such as extra living expenses, space heaters, or increased utility bills. The court’s analysis is limited to measuring rent abatement (difference between value as warranted and in defective condition) and makes no mention of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment or additional expense recovery. Thus the case does not support the specific proposition about being forced to incur extra living expenses in violation of habitability and quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “The trial judge found that the measure of damages was ‘the difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and the rental value of the apartment in its defective condition.’ … Apart from the question whether the tenant’s rent abates only after the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair, damages are not in dispute in this case.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s failure to ensure adequate heat also violated the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, which requires landlords to provide sufficient heating in habitable premises.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code provisions on heat and hot water, holding that the owner of a dwelling must supply heat and hot water unless a written letting agreement requires the tenant to supply the fuel. Because there was only an oral agreement here, the landlord remained obligated under the Code, so his failure to ensure adequate heat constituted a violation of the State Sanitary Code requirement to provide sufficient heat in habitable premises.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The tenant maintains that under the State Sanitary Code the landlord is not excused from his obligation to provide heat and hot water unless there is a writing transferring the obligation to the tenant. The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

*Simpson v. Young*, 369 Mass. 279 (1975).proposition: Defendant’s actions and inactions were willful and/or negligent.
*Simpson v. Young*, 369 Mass. 279 (1975).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns the constitutionality of Massachusetts’ mandatory death penalty statute for murder committed in the course of rape or attempted rape. It does not address standards for willful or negligent conduct, nor does it analyze a defendant’s actions or inactions in terms of negligence or willfulness. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that the defendant’s actions and inactions were willful and/or negligent.
*Simpson v. Young*, 369 Mass. 279 (1975).relevant_excerpt: We now address the issue whether the mandatory death penalty for murder committed in the course of rape or attempted rape, G. L. c. 265, § 2, is constitutional. For the reasons stated in the concurring opinions which follow, we hold that the mandatory death penalty for murder committed in the course of rape or attempted rape violates the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights and is unconstitutional.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Defendant’s actions and inactions were willful and/or negligent.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that liability under the quiet enjoyment statute requires at least negligent conduct and discusses landlord conduct that can be characterized as willful, reckless, or negligent. Although the case is about statutory quiet enjoyment in the context of lead paint, it clearly states that a landlord’s actions or inactions must involve some degree of fault (at least negligence) to give rise to liability, which supports the general proposition that a defendant’s conduct can be willful and/or negligent.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.
